pr_title: Issue #888 - add support to validate extensible and preferred binding

timeline.message:
Issue #888 - add support to validate extensible and preferred bindings

Signed-off-by: John T.E. Timm <johntimm@us.ibm.com>

Issue #888 - fixed failing unit tests in fhir-validation

Signed-off-by: John T.E. Timm <johntimm@us.ibm.com>

Issue #888 - fixed constraint generation issue

Signed-off-by: John T.E. Timm <johntimm@us.ibm.com>

Issue #888 - generate both vocab and value constraints

Signed-off-by: John T.E. Timm <johntimm@us.ibm.com>

Issue #888 - updates per failing tests

Signed-off-by: John T.E. Timm <johntimm@us.ibm.com>

timeline.bodyText: do we make the examples accessible from the registry, or we need it in the test dir too?
timeline.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: We do not make examples accessible from the registry. This example did not come from the IG package. It was in the IG github repo.
replies.author: JohnTimm

timeline.bodyText: Please update the class-level javadoc to indicate that we've added our own flavor of 'memberOf' which allows the caller to pass a binding strength
timeline.author: lmsurpre

timeline.bodyText: should it be a proper test?
timeline.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: This is more of a diagnostic driver to print out the generated constraints for manual inspection. I don't anticipate that we will make this part of the automated unit tests for this module.
replies.author: JohnTimm

timeline.bodyText: is it only warnings, or might we expect errors here too?
timeline.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: I made it flexible enough to support both.
replies.author: JohnTimm

replies.bodyText: but currently, an error will result in a thrown exception, right?  and presumably an empty list of issues?
replies.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: Added javadoc to clarify that these are "supplemental issues" used to convey additional information to the client.
replies.author: JohnTimm

timeline.bodyText: maybe a comment to explain this line?  like why do we only add the vocabulary constraint if the child has no constraints.
timeline.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: Added comments to clarify the behavior.
replies.author: JohnTimm

timeline.bodyText: will there ALWAYS be another constraint following this and?
timeline.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: if hasConstraint returns true on the check above it, then yes.
replies.author: JohnTimm

timeline.bodyText: quite a piece of logic here, maybe a comment to explain?
timeline.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: I have simplified this logic in the latest commit. It should be much easier to understand now.
replies.author: JohnTimm

timeline.bodyText: when is setting the constraint required?  when is it not required?
timeline.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: It is driven by the Validator to give the FHIRPathEvaluator and any FHIRPathFunction(s) access to it during evaluation. Thus far, the only function that cares about it is MemberOfFunction.
replies.author: JohnTimm

timeline.bodyText: when is unsetting the constraint required? when is it not required?
timeline.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: The unset is driven by the Validator (after it has evaluated the current constraint and before it changes to the context constraint).
replies.author: JohnTimm
